ratings.question_text: The readings/cases/textbooks used in this course were __________ .
Out-of-class assignments for this course were ___________ to my learning.
The workload for this course in comparison to other courses was ___________.
The pace of this class was ____________ for optimal learning.
Field trips were well designed and ran smoothly.
I learned a lot from field trips.
How clearly does the instructor provide explanations of conceptual material?
How responsive to student comments was the instructor?
I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:
Apart from how well the course was taught, how valuable is the course to students with interests similar to yours?
Did you participate in a work group as part of this course?

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-14, if you wish
comments: Excellent course; students come out of this course with a great skill set, applicable for research or work settings. Grading system was variable throughout the semester which was, for lack of a better word, annoying to deal with. Some assignments that I spent a lot of time of ended up being graded on and up/down scale. But all in all, what's important is that this class teaches you a lot!

1. Instructor is not necessary for student to learn the material. Lectures are hapazardly put together and a waste of time. Class material was self taught.2. Instructor needs to clarify, on day one, his expectations and grading framework. Throughout the semester his expectations of the students and project goals were constantly changing.3. Instructor sells the course as an introductory GIS course for those with no prior experience, however he only teaches to those in the top 5 or 10 percent of his grading scale. There needs to be an instructor who cares about the rest of the students.4. Bowers is an inappropriate space for this course. This course needs a lab component.
I do not believe that GIS can be properly taught through a lecture. It should be something that looks more like a lab, where the steps to achieve certain results are described in practice.

The class started very intensly and requires extra time and effort for non-GIS experienced students in the first place. Upon catching on the learning curve, it requires a standard amount of work, and allows for extra credits if desired

The skills in this course are incredibly valuable. I was a bit frustrated with the homework process - Ifound it to be incredibly stressful, and I wished I had a sense of the rubric or concepts we'd be graded on before I started assignments - I often felt like I was working in the dark, trying to guess what made one approach good or bad. This confusion often persisted after the assignments were turned in - we could see which projects did well or poorly, but I was less clear on *why.* The grading system also seemed to discourage people from working together, which is something that was really helpful later on in the course, when we formed teams.

#3 Completing the out of class assignment takes time but is well worth it.#1 You don't really have readings for the class but the handouts that are given to you to explain different features of GIS tools serve as a useful reference.#9 The class is large yet Professor Tomlin has always responded to my requests in a timely manner. His feedback is concise and instructive.

Professor Tomlin is a wonderful teacher in the sense that he is enthusiastic and instills some excitement and wonder about the subject matter, but his explanations really work for certain kinds of people and don't work very well for others. He is very conceptual but it was sometimes hard for those of us who are less naturally inclined to spatial problem solving to understand his approach.The reason I felt the course was not so suitable for students with interests similar to mine is that the course seemed geared toward people who would like to be using GIS themselves to solve problems during their careers. That's a bit more depth than I was looking for, which was to understand what GIS can do, to be able to have some facility with it, and to be able to interact with GIS specialists on a high enough level that I could ask them to solve certain problems for me.

I learned a lot from the assignments (which sometimes took 20 hours a week..) but it was worth it. The lectures though were too long and I couldn't followthem. At one time it's super basic, the next moment it's too in the weeds and I can't even understand what we are thinking.
Good class, but the pace was very fast

I think it would have been valuable to have some hands-on Lab time to interact with the software as we were discussing the concept - perhaps a 1 hour lecture, then 2 hours of guiding us through steps in the Lab. While the handouts were extremely detailed, I think the opportunity to ask questions while using the software would help facilitate the learning process.

narratives.question_text: What were the best aspects of this course?
comments: Well-organized entire course specifically including class material which was very helpful to follow up the class.

Dr. Tomlin is an excellent teacher. While I found his assignments vague and difficult to approach at time, this requiredstudents to think very differently about the data and tools in a way that facilitated deeper learning and understanding of the material.
Weekly assignments and being able to see other students' submissions.
I love how Dana's assignments are really puzzles to be solved. They really make you think and test your understanding of concepts.
-out of class assignments, opportunities to be creative

Got a good sense of the kind of thinking necessary to do really thorough GIS analysis. Really liked the process-oriented lectures at the end of the course, dealing with parallel v sequential modeling, etc.
A very interesting take on the intellectual work behind the models and high responsiveness of prof and TF.
Material provided online.
GIS is a great software, and I really enjoyed using it.
Stacey Maples.
Weekly assignments were very hands on and allowed for strong understanding of material taught in class.
Weekly assignments are challenging and by the end you will have a great understanding of raster methods in GIS.

Course offers a relatively easy to understand approach to conceptual thinking that is highly complex. Dana, being one of the major contributors to raster GIS is widely knowledgeable on the subject matter, and willing to be challenged by student questions
The way the professor makes an effort to explain raster is great. He really tries to make it as simple as possible.
I created a few maps I'm really proud of, and I feel I got a strong general sense of what this software is capable of.

GIS is a useful tool and after completing this course, I feel knowledgeable of a wide range of its capabilities and feel able to apply them to real world situations. In addition, I found Professor Tomlin's teaching style is very enjoyable.
I really came away with a solid understanding of GIS. it's a great class.
The professor and the lectures were the best aspects - Dr. Tomlin is extremely skilled at making somewhat abstract concepts clear and understandable (as well as discussing the mechanics of ArcMap).
The implementation of models
Building models and toolboxes
Hands on experience with GIS
The instructor's teaching style is very engaging, and effective at motivating us to learn the raster GIS. The assignments were interesting, relevant, and well-designed.

narratives.question_text: What aspects of this course need the most improvement?
comments: I struggled with knowing what Dr. Tomlin was looking for at times. Though I didn't perform as well as I would have liked particularly given the amount of time put into the weekly assignments, I learned a heck of a lot.
Sometimes the class sessions seemed to take longer than necessary, but it isn't that they weren't still interesting.
I kind of like how organic Dana's teaching is, but sometimes changing nature of course structure took a bit to cope with for a type A personality...
-variable grading system hard to follow

The grading system in this course didn't really work for me. I couldn't help thinking the instructor was making it up as he went along. I was told at one point that my grade was suffering because I was choosing not to do the optional brainteasers, which makes me wonder what the instructor's definition of "optional" really is.
Not sure if this was me or the course, but I found the assignments very difficult--even with all the help, I found it very challenging to figure out how to approach issues conceptually.
INSTRUCTOR-- give him the top 5 students and hire someone else for the rest of us.

I do not feel confident about using GIS and about the skills I learnt in this class because the assignments (which are the only moment when you really sit down to use the software) were individual and completely unguided! This made it unnecessarily incredibly time consuming, while having someone by my side to help me understand the concepts and the tools would have been fast and much more productive.
Instructor can be a bit difficult to approach-- a bit harsh at times.

Grading criteria for each assignment varies and lacks adequate explanation, many times feeling arbitrary.Some of the teaching techniques serve as enablers for overachievers. For instance, there are many, many opportunities for extra credit for those students with the time and drive to complete them. This resulted in a very skewed grading distribution at the end of the semester.
The grading scheme (per each assignment) is arbitrary, and tuned based on the average responses of the class members. It might be challenging to understand what is required/expected/graded at first
The class was extremely big and the classroom I felt was not the most appropriate. Getting a seat in the far back made it really hard to pay attention.

I found the process of turning in homework to be incredibly stressful - I really wish there were more tutorials, more group work, or some other kind of mechanism to be able to play around with concepts before beginning the process of starting an assignment. Pretty early on, a divide between people with GIS experience and those new to the course began to emerge, and I felt a bit frustrated about the lack of tools to help newer people catch up, especially when both homework assignments and overall grades were often made according to a curve (i.e., extra points given to the best homework assignments, etc.).
I didn't mind it but many people found the grading structure frustrating. I think it allows for flexibility and resilience (e.g gives opportunities to make up for a poor grade on an assignment).

The most infuriating thing about the course was how unclear it was at times how we were to be evaluated for our work. Sometimes the instructions were vague and grading criteria were only provided after our assignments were due. Sometimes it would be revealed only after we had turned in assignments that the assignments wouldn't be graded at all. I was unable to best allocate the hours I had available to all of my various class-related and non-class-related responsibilities because I didn't know when I needed to put in more effort on GIS versus when I could have devoted more time to something else that needed my attention.
The lectures.

Assignments need more of a rubric. It was difficult to know what we were being graded on (aside from one or two points in the agenda) and therefore to know what to include in the homework submission. Did all of the maps need legends/scales? Did some of them? Did we need to have 3-D maps? These are things that we were graded on, yet this was not made clear in the assignment. Also, if participation in brainteasers makes a difference in your end grade, even if the submissions do not get full points, this should be made clear at the beginning of the semester and not the end of the semester.
Actually, this is an excellent class.
Lectures could be faster paced. Also limiting the size of the course would be ideal.

A more clear plan for the end of the semester. A clearly explained roadmap for where we have been and where we are going would be very helpful if presented toward the end of the semester before the group assignment begins.
Shorter lecture and more Lab time.

narratives.question_text: Was the relationship between the course lectures and discussion/lab section
comments: It was quite effective.
n/a
Piazza was a great system for feedback and questions. Dana did a commendable job keeping up with it and responding quickly to students.
N/A
NONE
Having the tools described in a lecture does not adequately translate to the work done in the assignments.
Doing the class in a lab would be of great help to properly understand the tools.
N/A
Hard to see how they were related.
The lab sessions ( homeworks) were an excellent opportunity to better understand and apply the class concepts.
It would be helpful for the instructor to offer more feedback on solutions to assigned problems (homework and brainteasers) in class.
N/A

narratives.question_text: Discuss, if you wish, how this course fits into your overall program.  (Please feel free to describe how the course relates to your academic background.)
comments: I am a public health student, and took this course as a follow-up to a GIS course offered at YSPH. The course is geared towards forestry-related topics (understandably), so sometimes it was less clear how some applications would apply to public health. However, Dr. Tomlin always made a point to give examples outside of forestry/ecology. As my goal was to become more familiar with GIS and gain exposure to raster data, the course fit well with my personal goals, even if the link to the work I'm doing in my other coursework is less clear.
I'm really glad I've taken Raster - lots of employers like GIS.
will use these skills for future research
My background is fairly unrelated to this course. I took it to get a better understanding of the techniques used in scientific literature.
Material very useful and relevent for my field.
It is absolutely necessary because I work with biodiversity conservation, and it is very important for me to learn how to use GIS to map species and determine their distribution on a landscape.
My research interests involve a lot of large scale issues which are appropriately addressed with GIS.

I do urban planning and watershed management work and so spatial analysis and mapping are extremely valuable tools. I do not necessarily plan on being a GIS expert but I feel it is valuable to be able to perform basic tasks and have awareness of its capabilities.
This course was definitely helpful (almost necessary?) for FES744 Conservation Science. I don't know if I will need GIS skills in my future job, but I am glad to have them.
This course fits in my overall program as GIS is part of the information tools an environmental manager needs to implement efficient policies.

The course introduced me to a tool that will be used in the field of climate change adaptation planning, my principle area of focus here at FES and for my future career. I will now know how raster GIS can be used and what it can do, as well as some vector-based work as well.

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: To become more familiar with ArcGIS, as I am interesting in spatial mapping applications related to public health. I'm hoping to continue to work with the software in my work as an Epidemiologist.
I took vector a previous semester and definitely wanted to take raster as a followup. I'm glad I did. You can tell how passionate Dana is about the subject.
-to gain skills in raster GIS
I came here wanting to improve my GIS skills, and definitely felt like I achieved that.
Wanted GIS skills.
to learn GIS
It is fully important for my career.
Relevance to my field of work. Given the pervasiveness of computers, everything in the environment can be related through GIS.
The course is one of the few applied courses at the school. GIS is an important skill for environmental professionals, and Prof. Tomlin has a brilliant mind for the topic.
To further my knowledge base of GIS.

Sitting in the course now allows me to better understand GIS capabilities, and ways to work around the classic vector approach. It is very unlikely I will personally model in the future, however I feel strong if I have to interact with modelers (either requesting a task, or evaluating the work performed)
Because I loved the vector course.
GIS is so useful to so many of the topics I'm interested in - I felt like a basic fluency was required, and I was excited to play around with a new way for exploring data collection and analysis.

I took to course to learn more about raster GIS. I already had familiarity with vector-based analysis and wanted to round out the experience. I also wanted to take advantage of learning from Prof. Tomlin firsthand as he is an expert in this field.
I used it for my MEsc data analysis.
The possibility of needing it in the future/definitely needing it for another course.
I wanted to gain a better understanding of GIS
I took this course to gain skills in land use planning.
To learn GIS
Everyone recommended Dana as a fantastic teacher, and he did not disappoint. I had a vague feeling that raster GIS would come in handy in my career, but was not sure of its capabilities.

narratives.question_text: Did the knowledge/skills that you gained from the course meet your expectations ?
comments: Absolutely.
Definitely
Yes. Exceeded them actually. I feel like I can think differently about a whole host of problems (GIS related or not)>
yes
Yes. Makes me wish I had time to take vector as well. I'm a bit frustrated that the courses are divided up into vector/raster instead of intro/intermediate, but oh well.
Yes
Yes
Not at all, I wish I could have had more support. The class should be formatted as a lab, including team work and much support from the instructor/ta's!
Yes
Yes.
Yes, or even exceeded.
I learned more than I anticipated. It was awesome.
Yes

Kind of - I learned a great number of skills, but I still feel I'd need to play around with them a lot more to get a better sense of how they work and when it's more appropriate to apply different tools to different situations.
Yes. I have already been able to apply them to other projects I'm working on.
Definitely.
YES
Yes, the skills gained in this class meets my expectations
Not entirely. Because all the data used in class was provided by the instructor, I'm not sure how to search for, source, and navigate existing databases.
Yes

Yes. The final project was especially helpful in learning how to work with a client organization to take the data that they provide and use it to answer questions of a spatial nature. I also gained general but very useful problem-solving skills.

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: It was interesting to work in a group for the last few assignments. It offered a different view on how other students approach problems. Not surprisingly, I found the coordination of schedules most challenging, as I was working with students who are on a totally different schedule than mine.
Mimicked real world decision making process. Hard to coordinate schedules of course and felt like I would have liked to pursue some options that group didn't.

was great to learn from others approaches! advantage is was nice to problem solve together. disadvantage - the usual scheduling efforts. also, my group put a lot of work into group assignments that ended up being graded on up/down scale, so that was a bit frustrating.
Difficult tocoordinate scheduling, but that's not really Dana's problem.
Only advantages--made stumbling blocks less daunting and brainstorming more productive.
I eventually found a group of students to work with, but having individual assignments still made it very difficult to work as a team. Working in organized teams would have been much more helpful.
Discussion, sharing ideas and workload. Sometimes different opinions can result in process paralysis.

Group work went very smoothly in my circumstance. We worked well together, supplemented each others knowledge, and caught each others mistakes. The process went much faster than had it been done solo.

Team work is always challenging. It allows for multiple views in a discipline where there are no direct answers to solve most of the problems.However it also allowed for exchanging points of view and discussing different outcomes
The group really helped me better understand the logic of raster.
Group work was really helpful in learning from others, and in terms of thinking through tough challenges - I wish more opportunities for this had been built into the course earlier.

There are many ways to approach work in GIS and working in a group allowed me to learn more about how others are thinking about this. I also informally would work in groups on homework assignments and although not always the most efficient use of time, I found value in learning and exploring the tool with others.
Group work was essential in this course because there are so many ways to approach GIS problems, and talking strategies through with other people really helped with the learning process.
Working in group helped me to understand that a solution to a problem can be seen from different angles.
I found the group work to be very valuable. It provided more detailed discussion and feedback than what was achieved in class or possible when working alone.

Advantages: Everyone brings unique skills and knowledge, so it was great learning from other students whose experience in modeling and GIS work spanned a large range.Disadvantages: I do not see major disadvantages because group work is very close to how we will all work in our jobs after FES. The main downside is trying to coordinate schedules and to keep everyone accountable and completing tasks on time. This happens most of the time, but it can be frustrating when someone falls behind with their work or does not make meetings on time.
Allowed for brainstorming and the combined technical knowledge of individuals.

narratives.question_text: For students who might consider taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: It would be very good class for whom plan to extensively use the Arc-GIS class. Class note is well-organized for the entire subject covered in the class.
Take the course! I wish I would have taken the vector class as well, as I think Dr. Tomlin is an excellent teacher in GIS applications, and has a phenomenal command of ArcGIS.
Take it. The course not only gives you experience with GIS, it provides a new way to see and solve a whole host of problems.
-be prepared to do a lot!
do the brainteasers, even though they're optional
This is a hard course--don't take it lightly. Go to office hours. It's really worth it though! Brilliant prof and the concepts are really interesting.
DONT. download course materials and make it your summer project to learn the program. Its a waste of time to the inefficiencies of th einstructor.
Make sure to find a team to work with.

This will probably be your hardest course of the semester. It is a good course, but it is also time consuming, frustrating, and the grading is harsh. However, upon completion you will have a good understanding of how to manipulate raster data.
Do all the assignments as the requirements tend to fluctuate. Dedicate a LOT of time to homework.
Build time to get used to using ArcGIS, and the first assigments
Ask for the course to be taught in a lab.

I think the structure of the course changes dramatically from course to course, as Dana experiments with different teaching strategies, so these evaluations might not be an accurate depiction of what will await you next semester.
Take this course if you ever think you'll need GIS but be aware that it is a time commitment so plan accordingly.
Take the undergrad course if you, like me, are looking to have basic facility with GIS but not to have GIS be a central component of your future job.
It takes a ton of time!!
Do not wait until the last minute.Make use of the course website - you will get your questions answered there.
I think if you consider taking this class, take it, but be ready to work hard!

Put a lot of work in at the beginning to make sure you get the basic skill sets and tools before the course becomes increasingly difficult. It is extremely rewarding to track your improvement and your newly acquired skill in using GIS to solve problems and answer questions.
